• Anchor heavy appliances / furniture to the wall. 
 
 • Make a plan of where to meet your family after an earthquake. 
 
 • Make sure you have access to a fire extinguisher, first-aid kit, extra batteries, flashlight, and a battery powered radio. 
 
 • Get familiar with the earthquake plan at other locations like schools and offices.

• Learn how to prevent wildfires (most fires are caused by people usually during the summer months). 
 
 • Practice safety techniques (stop, drop, and roll). 
 
 • Make sure home and other belongings are insured. 
 
 • Prepare an emergency kit which should have three days worth of supplies for each member (water, emergency contacts, first aid, blankets, flashlight, batteries, nonperishable food, battery powered radio). 
 
 • Create a map and mark emergency exits. 
 
 • Keep a watch for local news about wildfires around you.

• Stay calm! 
 
 • If you are indoors stay inside and if you are outdoors stay outside. 
 
 • If you are indoors, stay away from windows and outside doors and instead crawl under heavy furniture or stand against a wall near the center of the building. 
 
 • If you are outdoors, stay away from power lines, buildings, and anything that might fall. 
 
 • Don’t use matches or candles because of potentially broken gas lines. 
 
 • If you are in a car, stop the car and stay inside.

• Be prepared to evacuate at any moment (usually a very short notice is given). 
 
 • Keep a watch of the news and obey officials and authorities. 
 
 • Consider soaking your entire property in water 
 
 • Keep windows and doors closed to limit exposure to dust.

• Turn on the radio and use phones for emergencies. 
 
 • Check yourself and others around you for injures and provide first aid to those that need it. 
 
 • Be careful of broken glass and other objects that may injure you. 
 
 • Stay away from beaches as tsunamis often hit after the earthquake 
 
 • Expect potential aftershocks. 
 
 • Stay away from damaged areas 
 
 • Check water, electric, and gas lines and if any are damaged, shut off the valves. If the smell of gas is present, open all windows and doors and exit the building.

• Pack supplies before heading back home such as garbage bags, gloves, goggles, closed toe shoes, and bottled water. 
 
 • Take pictures of damaged objects to make it easier for the insurance company to track what is damaged. 
 
 • Enter the house carefully and turn of the main power breaker immediately. 
 
 • Walk around the perimeter of the house before entering. 
 
 • Throw any food items out if the house was without power for a long time. 
 
 • Contact your home insurance broker to get started with repairs right away.
Your hazard index is a weighted value calculated based on your location and preparedness.
Your preparation index is calculated based on how many items you have prepared in your emergency kit.
The highest possible hazard index is 1.00. Assuming an average readiness score of 60%, the risk score of someone living near the San Andreas Fault would be 0.48.
An average preparation index would be around 60%.
